As we've learned recently from Victoria and elsewhere, thunderstorms can be a cause of asthma in certain people. Obviously, using an asthma preventer is the best way to reduce the asthma symptoms and flare-ups for people who have or are susceptible to this disease. It is, in many ways, a silent disease in terms of its incidence in the community, and it's worthwhile knowing that this can occur for many Australians. (Time expired)
Goods and Services Tax

Ms MADELEINE KING (Brand) (13:56): The muppet show of the Abbott-Turnbull-Morrison government rolls on, only now we have the potty-mouthed muppets here, led by the Prime Minister himself—the shouty, scream-y Prime Minister swearing at Tasmanians and calling them beggars. Let's see how that negotiation style's going to go when you try to get all the states and territories to agree to this empty GST plan. In WA yesterday, on radio, it has been reported that he apparently gave his word that the GST plan will be in place before the next election.
Ms Ryan: What word is that?

Ms MADELEINE KING: We don't know what word it is exactly. I bet he gave former Prime Minister Turnbull his word too, and where did that get him? It got him nowhere—just a luxury flat in New York. Congratulations! So he gave his word. I guess it's: job done, feet up—put your feet up, Prime Minister; go have a break! Why don't you just take off to New York with Malcolm? We've seen you do it before. This government refuses to give any detail to the Premier of Western Australia, who has requested detail for your GST plan. But you're not giving it, are you, member for Kooyong? Former Treasurer or Treasurer or whatever you are now—who knows? It's hard to keep up with you guys when you chop and change and move and so forth. We just don't know what's going on over there. What we do know is Western Australians on the other side didn't support a Western Australian to be Prime Minister of this country. We know that for certain.
Mr Frydenberg interjecting—
Ms MADELEINE KING: Yeah, you're terrific, mate! What I know is Labor will deliver a GST solution for all Western Australians. (Time expired)
Superannuation
Mrs SUDMALIS (Gilmore) (13:57): One of my constituents wrote:

I am writing to you to voice my strong opposition to the Australian Labor Party's proposal to disallow refunds of franking credits. This proposed policy will severely damage the retirement plans of many Australians who have prudently saved for retirement through a self-managed super fund and planned for refundable franking credits.

The current franking credit rules make sure that taxpayers receiving company profits will be taxed at their marginal tax rate on this income. This company tax paid on their behalf is credited to taxpayers to reduce their tax bill by the amount of tax the company has already paid. Where the taxpayer has a low or zero tax rate, such as an SMSF, this results in the tax paid by the company being refunded to them. This ensures that they are taxed appropriately on the income they receive from investing in Australian companies. This is a fair result under our tax system and is not a "loophole" or a "rort".

For SMSFs that are in retirement phase and have a zero-tax rate, the Labor policy will effectively impose a 30 per cent tax on profits received from Australian company shares they own. This is an unfair outcome for people in retirement phase, and a targeted tax on a popular asset class which is not replicated anywhere else in the Australian financial system.
Shame on you, Labor, shame!
Aged Care

Mr SHORTEN (Maribyrnong—Leader of the Opposition) (13:59): Today I have a very simple message for a remarkable group of Australians: thank you for working in aged care. Thank you to the 240,000 Australians working in residential care. Thank you to the 130,000 working in home and community care. Thank you for the dignity, the comfort and the reassurance you bring to the lives of the people whom we love. My colleagues and I appreciate that what you do is hard work. It's physically taxing—helping people in and out of bed and helping them shower and dress and eat—and then there's the emotional commitment too. You've got to be up and you've got to be on because the people that you care for are taking their cues from your demeanour every day.

Too often, though, people working in aged care do not receive the thanks and recognition that they deserve. But it is more than that: Australians working in aged care do not get from the government the support that they deserve, the training that they need or the staff numbers they require. And, too often, Australians working in aged care do not get the pay that they deserve. Labor believes that every Australian has the right to dignity and security in retirement. To everyone living in aged care and to everyone working in aged care and to everyone waiting for aged care, Labor will do better for you.
The SPEAKER: In accordance with standing order 43, the time for members' statements has concluded.
QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
Liberal Party Leadership

Mr SHORTEN (Maribyrnong—Leader of the Opposition) (14:00): My question is to the Prime Minister. Every day this week, the Prime Minister has refused to explain why Malcolm Turnbull is no longer Prime Minister of Australia. Last night on 7.30 he was asked the same question six times and six times he failed to answer the question. Will the Prime Minister now finally tell the Australian people why Prime Minister Turnbull is no longer the Prime Minister of Australia?

Mr MORRISON (Cook—Prime Minister) (14:01): Further to my earlier answers on this all week, Mr Speaker, I think it is time for the Leader of the Opposition to get over it. Get over it! It's time for you to get over it. It's time for you to focus on the things that matter to the Australian people: ensuring that we have an economy that remains—
Honourable members interjecting—

The SPEAKER: The Prime Minister will resume his seat. Members on both sides will stop shrieking and interjecting. Each day this week I've said what the consequences will be, and I'm not going to repeat myself all question time. Members who have been interjecting will consider themselves warned. The Prime Minister has the call.
Mr MORRISON: It's time the leader of the Labor Party actually focused on the things germane to the future of the Australian people.
Mr Brian Mitchell interjecting—
The SPEAKER: The member for Lyons will leave under 94(a).

span.span: The member for Lyons then left the chamber.

p.span: Mr MORRISON: The leader of the Labor Party should focus on how an economy is kept strong to guarantee the essential services that Australians rely on, because I know that the leader of the Labor Party has no clue when it comes to keeping an economy strong and he has no clue about how to ensure that you balance a budget. He stands in this place and he makes bold promises and claims and engages in a gush of empathy, but he has no practical ability to deliver one promise to one person in Australia, because he has no ability to manage a strong economy or manage a budget—neither he nor the shadow Treasurer, or any of those who were proven failures when they were last in government when it came to managing the nation's finances.
Ms Plibersek interjecting—
Mr MORRISON: The Australian people know why the leader of the Labor Party should not be the Prime Minister—because he's not up to the job.
Ms Plibersek interjecting—
The SPEAKER: If the Deputy Leader of the Opposition didn't occupy that position, she would have been ejected by now—but that is her final warning.
Morrison Government

Mrs SUDMALIS (Gilmore) (14:03): My question is to the Prime Minister. Will the Prime Minister advise the House on how the government's plan to 'keep Australians together' will create an even stronger Australia?

Mr MORRISON (Cook—Prime Minister) (14:03): I thank the member for Gilmore for her question and for her passionate service to her community and the Australian people. Our plan for an even stronger Australia is about keeping our economy strong to guarantee the essential services that Australians rely on, as we discussed in the House yesterday, to keep Australians safe—and the Liberal and National parties know all about that task and have demonstrated that in this government over the last five years and when we were last in government—and, importantly, to keep Australians together. Our plan to keep Australians together is about standing with Australians, their families and their communities—to have their back and to back those families and those Australians—and ensuring that we respect all of their beliefs, that we listen to all of their views, that we acknowledge all of their concerns, that we appreciate all of their contributions as Australians, and that we stand with them to protect the freedoms which they hold dear.

We are standing together with families and small businesses to lower their taxes to ensure they keep more of what they earn and to ensure they have cheaper electricity prices through the policies pursued by this government. We are standing with rural and regional Australians, particularly those affected by the drought, to ensure that their health and their education services continue to be delivered and can be paid for by our strong financial management. We stand with them to achieve the drought relief, the recovery and the hope that they seek and that they are after.

We are standing with young people and women, as we are seeing young people and women getting into jobs and participating in our economy in record numbers. The gender wage gap has come to the lowest level in many years. We're seeing that gap condensed. We're seeing female participation in the labour force rise, and we saw 95,500 young people get a job under the watch of this government—the best result in 30 years for a fiscal year.

We're standing with parents in Australia so the choices they make for how their children should be educated can be protected and preserved. No-one should get between a parent and their child when it comes to the choices those families make to ensure that the education those parents want for those children can be preserved in the way that they choose and so that they get the affordable child care that gives those families choices.

We're standing with migrant communities; we're recognising their continued success. We're the most successful immigration country in the world today, and we know that migrant communities come to make a contribution, not take one. We're standing for those people of faith and belief in this country, and only this government can be guaranteed, relied upon and trusted to protect— (Time expired)
Women in Parliament

Ms PLIBERSEK (Sydney—Deputy Leader of the Opposition) (14:06): My question is to the Prime Minister. Last night on 7.30 the Prime Minister rejected gender quotas, saying, 'It should be a matter of one's own effort and exertion and credibility and merit.' Was the Prime Minister honestly saying that the reason women are paid less, have fewer leadership roles in business and are less represented in important national institutions is because they display less effort, less credibility and less merit than men?

Mr MORRISON (Cook—Prime Minister) (14:07): No, I'm not saying that at all. And I'm not going to be verballed by the Deputy Leader of the Labor Party, which she has a habit of doing. She might want to explain to me why Senator Singh, a very respected member of the other place, was relegated to No. 4 on the ticket.
Ms Rishworth interjecting—
Mr Falinski interjecting—
Mr MORRISON: Why was she relegated to No. 4 on the ticket? From memory, she was relegated to No. 4 on the ticket because she wouldn't join up with one of your mob's factions.
Ms Rishworth interjecting—
Mr Falinski interjecting—
The SPEAKER: The members for Kingston and Mackellar will leave under 94(a).

span.span: The members for Kingston and Mackellar then left the chamber.

p.span: Mr MORRISON: As I was saying, because Senator Singh wouldn't join up with one of the bother factions of the Labor Party, she was relegated, and I'll tell you why: it's because under the Labor Party show and tell on your vote isn't an exception; it's the rule. The Deputy Leader of the Labor Party admitted today that show and tell on votes is actually okay because they're a collective group. It's okay to do that if it's institutionalised. That's the way of the Labor Party.

The Leader of the Labor Party says he wants to run the country like a union. He runs the Labor Party like a union, and we know how the unions intimidate on building sites. We know that the led, bred and fed approach of the union movement with this Leader of the Labor Party has infused their entire culture, and that's what he wants to bring to the leadership of this country. This is why the Leader of the Labor Party can't be trusted.
He likes to talk about these issues. Well, where was he when the member for Lindsay was subjected to the roughhouse tactics of her members out there in Western Sydney?

Where was he when, apparently, there had been a formal investigation underway for about a year in the Labor Party and he knew nothing? He knew absolutely nothing when questioned on these issues. His attention to these sorts of matters in his own party was to stick his head under the table and pretend they weren't there.
DISTINGUISHED VISITORS

The SPEAKER (14:10): I inform the House that we have joining us in the gallery this afternoon a parliamentary delegation from the Northern Territory, led by the Speaker of the Legislative Assembly, Kezia Purick. On behalf of the House I extend a very warm welcome to you.
Mr Rob Mitchell interjecting—

The SPEAKER: If the member for McEwen is incapable of not interjecting, the standing orders are there to deal with it. He well knows it, particularly when I'm welcoming guests. They certainly haven't come to see that. I also inform the House that we have joining us in the gallery this afternoon the honourable Peter Slipper, former member and Speaker of this House. On behalf of the House I extend a very warm welcome.
Honourable members: Hear, hear!
Mr Pyne interjecting—
The SPEAKER: I have a schedule here, Leader of the House. If he wants to come and do it, we can do that, but I actually time them through question time. All right? Would you like a welcome as well?
QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
Taxation

Mr HOWARTH (Petrie) (14:11): My question is to the Treasurer. Will the Treasurer please update the House on how the government is standing together with families and small businesses to deliver legislated tax relief, including for businesses in my electorate of Petrie? Is the Treasurer aware of any higher taxing alternative opinions?

Mr FRYDENBERG (Kooyong—The Treasurer) (14:12): I thank the member for Petrie for his question. He, like 25 million other Australians, knows that the government can be trusted to deliver good economic management and that the Labor Party can't be trusted to run the economy and can't be trusted with money. And, if they can't be trusted with money, they end up coming after yours.

The Australian economy is growing at 3.4 per cent. We've created more than one million new jobs and we're bringing the budget back to balance earlier than expected in 2019-20. Fundamental to our economic plan is providing tax relief to millions of Australian families and businesses. We have legislated tax relief to ensure that 10 million Australians are getting a benefit of up to $530 a year at first stage, that 94 per cent of taxpayers pay no more than 32.5c in the dollar, and that more than three million small- and medium-sized enterprises will benefit from our tax plan.

I can confirm to the House that earlier in the Senate today our $20,000 instant asset write-off extension has gone through, and more than 300,000 businesses have benefited from our instant asset write-off. This stands in stark contrast to what those opposite are offering the Australian people—$200 billion in additional taxes. Under the Labor Party, you'll pay more on your income, you'll pay more on your business, you'll pay more on your property and you will, as a retiree, have your savings raided. That is what will happen under the Labor Party. If you're in Petrie and you're a forklift driver, you will pay up to $4½ thousand more in tax under the Labor Party's plan than ours. If you are a small local supermarket, you will pay up to $10,000 more in tax under Labor's plan if you were running that business in Petrie, employing young people.

So Australians have a clear choice at the next election. They can have the tax-and-spend policies of those opposite or they can have the proven economic management of the coalition, which has created more than one million jobs and is leaving more money—the hard-earned money of Australians—in their pockets.
Drought

Mr FITZGIBBON (Hunter) (14:15): My question is to the Prime Minister. Why did the Prime Minister tweet and authorise a video containing the following statement: 'Drought is a necessary evil. It can help cut out that bottom 10 per cent that probably shouldn't be there anyway'. Neither the member for Warringah nor Malcolm Turnbull would ever have promoted a statement like that. Why is it that, at the same time Australians are making an extraordinary effort to help our farmers in drought, the Prime Minister is promoting material that dismisses those farmers hurting most?
Mr McCormack interjecting—
The SPEAKER: The Deputy Prime Minister is interrupting the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister has the call.

Mr MORRISON (Cook—Prime Minister) (14:16): I thank the member for the question. That matter is of no recollection to me. I'd be pleased if the member could provide me with the details, and I'll be happy to review it.
Opposition members interjecting—
The SPEAKER: Members on my left. If members on my left could cease interjecting—the member for Ballarat. The member for Hunter is seeking leave?
Mr Fitzgibbon: If it assists the Prime Minister, I'm happy to table the transcript.
The SPEAKER: You just need to seek leave. It's very simple.
Mr Fitzgibbon: I seek leave to table the transcript of the tweet in question.
Leave not granted.
Mr Albanese: He just asked for it!
The SPEAKER: The member for Grayndler will cease interjecting.
Climate Change

Ms McGOWAN (Indi) (14:16): My question is to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, my community of Indi wants action on climate change. They know that the future is with renewable energy and they want the government to lead the way. Prime Minister, you said the NEG is dead, but there's no legislation setting emission targets, and yet you remain committed—which we welcome—to the Paris agreement. Prime Minister, what's next? What is the future of the Renewable Energy Target? What action is government going to take on climate change? Can you please share what your plans are not only for my electorate of Indi but for all of us in regional Australia who rely so closely on the climate for our living?

Mr MORRISON (Cook—Prime Minister) (14:17): I thank the member for Indi for her question. Australia has met our emissions targets that have fallen due to date. Australia will meet the emissions targets that we have set for the future in both 2020 and 2030. Australians are doers; they're not talkers about these things. We have a proud record of meeting the commitments that we agreed to and we set for ourselves in these international forums. That's why we remain committed to these agreements; because we would not want to cast any doubt on our commitment to other agreements. When we make a commitment and we set our minds to those targets in those international fora, we pursue them. Kyoto 1 we cleared by 128 million tonnes. With Kyoto 2 in 2020 we anticipate meeting that by in excess of 294 million tonnes. There was a billion-tonne turnaround from what was occurring under the Labor Party to what is now occurring under the policies of this government over the last five years. Emissions are at the lowest level per capita and as GDP in the last 28 years, and in electricity it's the lowest since September of 2000.

We will meet the 2030 Paris targets. Our suite of policies, which includes the Emissions Reductions Fund, the small-scale and the large-scale RET, the Clean Energy Finance Corporation and, indeed, what will be the great legacy of Prime Minister Turnbull—Snowy 2.0, a significant investment in renewable and dispatchable power for Australia's future—will all assist us in meeting this target, and the energy efficiency measures and the demand management measures equally make up our policy to meet those targets.

We're doing it also without sacrificing jobs. More than a million jobs have been created while we've been going about this billion-tonne turnaround that we inherited from the Labor Party. Our commitments are clear, our policies are clear and our intentions are clear.
DISTINGUISHED VISITORS

The SPEAKER (14:19): Just before I call the member for Murray, it's my pleasure to also welcome today in the southern gallery the former Speaker, the Hon. Harry Jenkins, who is here with the Global Voices program. Welcome back.
Honourable members: Hear, hear!
QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
Regional Australia

Mr DRUM (Murray—Nationals Whip) (14:19): My question is to the Deputy Prime Minister, Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development. Will the Deputy Prime Minister update the House on how the government is standing together with regional communities to deliver services Australians rely on in rural and regional Australia, including in health and education? Are there any risks to this investment in regional Australia?

Mr McCORMACK (Riverina—Deputy Prime Minister, Minister for Infrastructure,Transport and Regional Development and Leader of The Nationals) (14:20): I thank the member for Murray for his question. He, like all of us on this side of the House, knows and understands that strong regions build a strong economy. Strong regions build a strong country and that's what we're committed to each and every day. Good economic management is good for regional Australia. When the regions are strong, so too is our nation. We've helped small businesses, particularly those in the member for Murray's electorate and elsewhere in regional Australia, create a million jobs in five years. We have given tax cuts to small businesses, particularly in regional Australia, that make such a difference—$1.4 billion in regional programs and billions more in regional infrastructure with more to come. This investment is about more doctors in the bush through the Murray-Darling Rural Medical Schools Network. That is going to be important infrastructure to help more doctors so that they can train from end to end. We know that when they train in the bush, chances are they'll stay in the bush.

I have to compliment the Minister for Health, who has enabled, thanks to our strong economy, more drugs to go on the PBS such as ORKAMBI. When you talk about ORKAMBI, you talk about Jack and Annelise Golder from Temora shire. They go to school in Ariah Park in my electorate. They are just young kids. They want the best possible future and they are going to have that. They're cystic fibrosis sufferers but, thanks to having a strong economy, we can put more life-saving drugs on the PBS and it is kids like Jack and Annelise who are going to benefit from that.

We on this side are also fixing Labor's independent youth allowance mess so country kids don't have their potential limited by their postcode. We're lifting the parental income cut-off for the work force participation independence criteria for regional students from $150,000 to $160,000 and by a further $10,000 for each additional child in the family. We've appointed a National Rural Health Commissioner, Dr Paul Worley, and I pay tribute to the member for Lyne for his work in that regard and, as well, former Senator Fiona Nash when she was the rural health minister. I think she would make a very good member for Eden-Monaro. I do, absolutely.

There's job-creating productivity-enhancing infrastructure, of course, as well, such as upgrades to the north-east rail line that's going to benefit people in the Murray electorate, such as the Echuca-Moama bridge across the Murray River. In the $20 million regional jobs and investment package, there will be 21 projects in the member who asked the question's electorate, which will create more than 750 jobs in the region, and more than 440 of those will be ongoing. What do we see from those opposite? We see no money for mobile phone towers, no idea, no vision for regional Australia. That's what those opposite stand for and, rest assured, it will be an absolute mess if ever that man there becomes Prime Minister. (Time expired)
DISTINGUISHED VISITORS
The SPEAKER (14:23): Just before I call the member for Franklin, I'd like to welcome to the gallery this afternoon the former Deputy Premier of New South Wales, Carmel Tebbutt.
Honourable members: Hear, hear!
QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
Tasmania

Ms COLLINS (Franklin) (14:23): My question is to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister confirm that since the last federal election, he's spent more time in Germany than he has in Tasmania? When is the Prime Minister going to stop shouting at Tasmanians and start showing us the respect we deserve? Finally, when will the Prime Minister finally bring down the curtain on what is described as his government's muppet show?

Mr MORRISON
( Cook — Prime Minister ) ( 14:24 ): I thank the member for her interest in my diary and my travel habits. This is what the government I've been part of has done for Tasmania: the Cradle Mountain cable car, $30 million; Burnie soccer club, $500,000; the Latrobe club mitigation works, $3.4 million; $300,000 for the Devonport Gymnastics Club; $2.5 million for Ulverstone Cultural Precinct; $350,000 for the West Park upgrade; the Bass Highway upgrade of $60 million; the Murchison Highway upgrade of $10 million; the King Island Child Care and Early Learning Centre, $300,000; the Rotary Club of Ulverstone community facility, $55,000; the Devonport Living City waterfront project, $10 million; $70,000 for the Coastal Motocross Club; the Irishtown Community Centre, $25,000; Phoenix Community House men's shed, King Island, $125,000; the Ridgley Football Club and Ridgely Cricket Club, $35,000; the Ulverstone cricket club, $70,000; and the Wynyard BMX park at $200,000.

That is total funding of some $3.8 billion in 2018-19, an increase of $28.5 million since the last budget in specific-purpose payments and other payments to the state of Tasmania. That's what I call recognising Tasmania—running a strong economy, working with Premier Will Hodgman and Treasurer Gutwein in Tasmania to ensure a strong economy that is delivering for Tasmanians. But there is a great risk to Tasmania, a terribly great risk to Tasmania. Thankfully, at the last state election they averted the election of a Labor government there, but there is still the great risk for Tasmania that, if those opposite, the Labor Party, get their hands on the Australian economy, Tasmania will suffer under their management.
Employment

Ms FLINT (Boothby) (14:26): My question is to the Minister for Jobs, Industrial Relations and Women. Will the minister update the House on how the government is standing together with women and young people to help more women and young people enter the workforce with the help of our strong economic plan? How does this compare with alternative approaches?

Ms O'DWYER (Higgins—Minister for Jobs, Industrial Relations and Women) (14:26): I thank the member for her question. The government knows how important it is to get more Australians into more jobs. We know that jobs create improved financial security for millions of Australians and, when millions of Australians have got increased financial security, they have more choices about their lives. Pleasingly, the government's economic plan is working and we know that young people and women are seeing the benefits.

Women have been employed under our government in record numbers: more than six million women. This, of course, compares with those opposite. We've seen an additional 600,000 women employed under our government, compared to when they left office. We have seen more than a million jobs created under our government, with the majority of those jobs having been taken up by women. Full-time employment for women is, as we speak, at record levels, with double-digit growth since 2013 when the government formed office.

When it comes to young people, we have seen 95,000 young Australians finding employment in 2017-18, which is the best result in a financial year for around 30 years. It's absolutely critical that young people are able to get in and get a job, because it delivers for them not only financial security but also the skills, knowledge and expertise they need. When those opposite left office, how many young people had lost jobs? Twenty thousand of them had lost jobs.

Our Transition to Work program is also achieving real results for people aged between 15 and 21. We're making sure that they have proper pre-employment assistance so that they are not becoming long-term unemployed. We know that young people want more flexible and innovative ways to work and we have a self-start program for those young people. We've got facilitators making sure that those who want to be enterprising and start a business will be able to do just that.

Those opposite need to appreciate that when people get a job they need to be paid well and, for women, it is important to close the gender pay gap. Under those opposite, when they were last in government, the gender pay gap stood at 17.2 per cent. Under our government, it has been narrowed to 14.5 per cent, a record low. We do know that there is still more work to be done, but things under our government are actually heading in the right direction. As Minister for Women, for the first time I will be delivering a women's economic security statement—for the first time ever—focused on these issues, because we stand with women and we stand with— (Time expired)
Banking and Financial Services

Mr SHORTEN (Maribyrnong—Leader of the Opposition) (14:29): My question is to the Prime Minister. Yesterday the banking royal commission heard shocking evidence that Grant Stewart's son, who has Down syndrome, was bullied into signing up for insurance that he didn't want, need or even understand. At the time this occurred the Prime Minister had already voted against a royal commission and ridiculed people for calling for this royal commission. Will the Prime Minister at least now apologise to Mr Stewart and his son for voting against the royal commission 26 times and calling it a 'populist whinge'?

Mr MORRISON (Cook—Prime Minister) (14:30): When I heard that report, it was shocking. It was despicable. I am pleased that, ultimately, the matter was rectified, but that doesn't condone it or forgive it in any way, shape or form. When I became Treasurer, my approach was, and has always been, to try and fix problems as I find them.

In relation to the matters that were plaguing our banking and financial industry, we moved quickly. The Minister for Jobs and Industrial Relations, who was then the Minister for Revenue and Financial Services, took action to deal with the serious problems occurring in our banking and financial industry. We increased the resources for ASIC. We increased the penalties. We increased its powers. We introduced the toughest accountability regime legislated in this place for banking and financial institutions in the country. We didn't stop; we kept going and we've continued to add to all of those measures.

As I was seeking to solve those problems—because that's my nature; if I see a problem and a need, then I will seek to fix it—the problem I didn't see and I should have seen, the problem that also needed to be addressed, was the hurt that people were feeling as a result of the banking and financial sector. I regret not having done that earlier for that reason. The reason I made the comments I did at the time is that I wasn't going to go around Australia and promise hurting people that they would get outcomes from a royal commission that would change their circumstances. I was never going to promise that. Those who did that, like those opposite, were giving people false hope and engaging in a form of cruelty that I would not engage in.

It is true that I do regret that, of all the problems I was seeking to address in the banking and financial industry, the real hurt being felt by Australians also needed to be addressed. So I regret that we did not do it earlier. I am pleased it is happening now. In addition to that, the commissioner will report in September, this month, and at the end of that review of their interim report we will make further decisions on how we progress from there.
DISTINGUISHED VISITORS

The SPEAKER (14:32): I would like to inform the House that we've just had join us in the gallery this afternoon the Australian Political Exchange Council's 22nd Delegation from Vietnam. On behalf of the House, I extend a very warm welcome to you.
Honourable members: Hear, hear!
QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
Schools

Mr LAMING (Bowman) (14:33): My question is to the Minister for Education. Would the minister update the House on how the government is standing together with parents and families to ensure more choice in education and schooling of their children and, of course, in accessing affordable child care? Is the minister aware of any other proposals?

Mr TEHAN (Wannon—Minister for Education) (14:33): I would like to thank the member for his question. I know that he is passionate about ensuring choice when it comes to education for all parents in his electorate of Bowman. The coalition believes in a well funded and fairly funded public education system, in a well and fairly funded Catholic education system, and in a well and fairly funded independent schools sector. We all want the best for our children. As a coalition government we believe in the right of Australian parents to choose when it comes to education. Why? Because it is fundamental to allow them to provide the best outcome for their children.

Over the last decade, funding from the Commonwealth for government schools has increased by 87 per cent and enrolments have increased by 10 per cent. For non-government schools, Commonwealth funding has increased by 73 per cent and enrolments have increased by 11 per cent. We support all school sectors. We're enthusiastic in our support for all school sectors. We believe that choice is important because it's a core value of coalition governments. It's why we are providing record funding to government schools, record funding to Catholic schools and record funding to independent schools.
In terms of non-government education, gradually the federal government has become a larger and larger contributor. Why? As John Howard has said:
Though a product of the government school system and proudly so, I believe in choice—
It's about giving people the capacity to control their own lives and to make informed choices over the course of their lives.
… quality demands choice, diversity, specialisation, transparency and competition.

We will make sure that we give the greatest funds to those school communities which can least afford it but we will also make sure that we provide choice. That's a fair approach. It's a principled approach. It's an approach about empowering parents so that they have options for their children.

The member for Bowman asked about other options. The problem is that when it comes to those opposite, we know that, in their heart of hearts, they don't believe in choice. We know that, in their heart of hearts, they do not believe in giving parents the right to choose for their children.
Banking and Financial Services

Mr BOWEN (McMahon) (14:36): My question is to the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister delayed a royal commission into the banks for almost two years, calling it a 'populist whinge'. Is the Prime Minister aware that this week the royal commission heard that one insurance company broke the law over 300,000 times? Instead of making excuses, when will the Prime Minister apologise to Australians for running a protection racket for bad behaviour and voting against the royal commission 26 times?

Mr MORRISON (Cook—Prime Minister) (14:37): I'm not sure if the shadow Treasurer didn't hear my response to the last question. What I just made very, very clear was my deep regret, for the reasons that I outlined. I'm pleased that the royal commission is now proceeding. The matters that have been presented at the royal commission are deeply disturbing but, as the shadow Treasurer would know, the matters that the commission is investigating happened on so many occasions on the watch of those who sit opposite. They did not initiate a royal commission when they were in government. They did not even support a financial system inquiry when they were in government. This is an opposition that is a lion when in opposition but a mouse when in government. When they come in this place and they raise these issues, completely blind to their own failings, their own culpability and their own lack of empathy, they only expose to the Australian people the shallowness of their position. I'll invite the Treasurer to add to my answer.

Mr FRYDENBERG (Kooyong—The Treasurer) (14:38): Absolutely right; the ClearView experience and the 300,000 alleged breaches by providing unsolicited advice were clearly wrong. As the Prime Minister has indicated, we have taken a number of steps. We have granted ASIC increased penalties and increased resourcing. We have ensured that there's a financial complaints authority. We've put in a second deputy commissioner, Daniel Crennan, at ASIC with specific responsibility for tackling this misconduct.

Let's not forget that when the Labor Party were in office—do you remember these terrible events? Storm Financial; 4,000 clients suffered losses estimated to be $3 billion. It occurred on Labor's watch. Opes Prime; 1,200 investors costing millions of dollars. It occurred on Labor's watch. The collapse of Trio Capital—
Mr Thistlethwaite interjecting—
The SPEAKER: The member for Kingsford Smith!
Mr FRYDENBERG: which had 5,000 victims costing $176 million—
Mr Thistlethwaite interjecting—
The SPEAKER: The member for Kingsford Smith is warned.
Mr FRYDENBERG: occurred on Labor's watch. They did nothing when they were in government. Again, it's up to us to clean up Labor's mess.
Religious Freedom

Mr LEESER (Berowra) (14:39): My question is to the Attorney-General. Will the Attorney-General update the House on how the government is standing together with religious communities to prevent religious discrimination and to protect freedom of religion? What are the risks of different approaches?

Mr PORTER (Pearce—Attorney-General) (14:40): I thank the member for Berowra for his question and I understand his deep and abiding interest. I might just briefly note on indulgence that it is Prostate Cancer Awareness Month. I say to all the men out there, 'Get the check,' and say, for a family with a father in chemo in at the moment, 'Hang in there, dad.'

On 7 December last year this parliament passed—after a national plebiscite process—the very historic bill to amend the Marriage Act. Strengthening the rights to equality before the law for same-sex couples in Australia is something of which this government and this parliament can be very proud. The process itself also demonstrated that unavoidable reality about how democratic systems define and protect rights—being the reality that liberties don't always neatly coexist and dovetail into some a perfect system where all rights simultaneously are achievable without some compromises. More often than not, rights collide and require consideration and compromises. So equality before the law is considered in the context of freedoms of association and religious expression.

Finding the best common compromise in modern Australia has not been a process that has always paid enough and due consideration to freedoms of association and freedoms of religion. That is why this government, on 22 November 2017, appointed Philip Ruddock to chair an expert panel to examine whether Australian law adequately protects these fundamental human rights. But this isn't a new issue. In 1998, the then Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission reported that many Australians suffered religious discrimination and just last year the UN expressed a concern about the lack of direct protection against discrimination on the basis of religion at the federal level in Australia.

In being asked about alternatives, it does strike the government that one of the problems about doing nothing in this area is demonstrated by a very recent matter that arose in Queensland where a Baptist Community Care organisation did something that many organisations did during the plebiscite, which was that they put a view about the plebiscite to their employees—in a very modest and respectful way, I might add. They faced a full discrimination and vilification action in Queensland and, having been successfully cleared of that action, now face a Queensland Industrial Relations Commission action.

The importance of this issue to Australians is evidenced by the fact that the panel received over 15,000 submissions and had 90 consultation meetings. As our government finalises its response to the report, I would like to thank the members of that committee for their diligence. I might note that the process that we will all need to embark on is going to require some common ground and some care and consultation. But the alternative to doing nothing in this space is to consider religious freedom as somehow a second-order right that deserves less protection than discrimination based on sex, race or age. This government does not consider religious freedom a second-order right.

Mr Shorten: Mr Speaker, following on from the Attorney-General's answer, the Labor Party wants to engage in this debate; so will he please table the Ruddock report—which, so far, the government has not provided to the opposition?
The SPEAKER: Was the Attorney quoting from confidential documents?
Mr Porter interjecting—
The SPEAKER: Okay. Alright, I will just treat that as a request. I didn't hear the Attorney quoting from the document.
Mr Shorten: He mentioned 15,000 submissions and 90 consultations. He, clearly, was referring—
Mr Morrison interjecting—
Mr Shorten: So you're now saying that the Attorney-General wasn't referring to the Ruddock report? Why are you hiding it?
The SPEAKER: The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat.
Mr Dreyfus interjecting—

The SPEAKER: The member for Isaacs will resume his seat. I say to both sides that it's a very straightforward issue. Certainly the Ruddock report was referred to. At no point did I hear the Attorney say he was quoting from it. He referred to the number of submissions and all the rest. The rules are clear around requesting documents to be tabled in question time, and they relate to documents that the minister has been quoting from. He's made it clear that that doesn't fall into that category. I didn't hear anything that made it the case, and I don't want to see question time move to an area where we're just asking each other to table documents from all over the place. So that matter is settled for the time being.
Minister for Home Affairs

Mr DREYFUS (Isaacs—Deputy Manager of Opposition Business) (14:44): My question is to the Minister for Home Affairs. Clause 2.11 of the Statement of Ministerial Standards requires the minister to avoid conflicts between his private interests and his official duties. But, according to media reports, the minister chose to participate in government discussions on the childcare industry to offer what he said was the 'point of view of operators'. Does the minister consider he has complied with clause 2.11 of the ministerial standards, when his childcare businesses have reportedly received in excess of $5 million in taxpayers' money and he chose to participate in those discussions about child care?

Mr DUTTON (Dickson—Minister for Home Affairs) (14:45): I thank the shadow Attorney for his question. I have always complied with the cabinet rules. I have declared any interests that I've had in any discussion. I've been very clear about that. I've recused myself from discussions where that's been deemed appropriate. I have seen some erroneous media reports, but I can't add anything further than that.
Drought

Mr GEE (Calare) (14:45): My question is to the Minister for Agriculture and Water Resources. Will the minister update the House on how the government is standing together with drought affected primary producers to provide support and build resilience in regional and remote communities, including in the electorate of Calare?

Mr LITTLEPROUD (Maranoa—Minister for Agriculture and Water Resources) (14:46): I thank the honourable member for his question. He has an acute understanding of this drought, particularly in his electorate of Calare in New South Wales. He is proud that this government has invested over $1.9 billion into farming communities and farms themselves throughout this drought.

It's important that we understand that it's the state governments' responsibility to look after animal welfare, freight and fodder throughout a drought. It's the federal government's responsibility to look after farmers' welfare. Proudly, our government lifted the Farm Household Allowance assistance to $37,626 a year to give farmers the dignity and respect they need, to allow them to be able to pay for household expenses and to give them the time to make tough decisions.

We've complemented that with a further $8½ million for rural financial counsellors. These are the angels of the drought. These are the people who go out and sit around the kitchen tables of farmers and give them the strategic advice they need. I'm proud to advise the House today that I've given approval for a further 39 Rural Financial Counselling Service staff to complement the already existing 116 staff. They will go into electorates like Calare as soon as possible.

But we're not just thinking about the here and now; we're also thinking about the future. We're making sure that we have preparedness and resilience in place in our measures and our policies for drought. I'm also proud to announce today to the House that our government will invest a further $15 million into pest and weed control for drought affected communities. This takes our investment up to $40 million for pest and weed control in drought affected communities. This is allowing farmers to attack weeds of national significance, weeds that cost our agricultural sector around $4 billion a year.

More importantly, it's about building the thousands of kilometres of dog-exclusion fencing; it is about bringing sheep back into our country and bringing shearers back into our towns. This is a strategic investment not only in the profitability of agriculture but also in environmental outcomes. Because of this investment we're seeing brolgas and koalas and small marsupials coming back into western Queensland and New South Wales for the first time. It's a strategic investment in the profitability of agriculture. We're seeing, for the first time, an increase in lambing rates, from seven to 85 per cent. That's putting real money in people's pockets.

This is an important investment, but we want to be bolder than that. We're making a big investment in water infrastructure. We're making a bold invest of nearly $500 million in trying to droughtproof this nation. We've got eight projects already underway, and three more planned to start in the near future. This is making sure that we are having a strategic impact on the future of agriculture's productivity and profitability, but it's the states' responsibility to build dams. We are doing our bit. I put my hand out to them today to come on that journey and droughtproof this nation with us, believing in agriculture, believing in water and believing in regional and rural Australia. (Time expired)
Minister for Home Affairs

Mr DREYFUS (Isaacs—Deputy Manager of Opposition Business) (14:49): My question is to the Prime Minister. When asked in question time whether the Minister for Home Affairs excused himself from all discussions on child care owing to his interest in childcare centres, Malcolm Turnbull undertook to seek advice from the Cabinet Secretary and report back to the House. Given the government shut down the parliament before Mr Turnbull had the opportunity to provide this advice, will the Prime Minister now honour Malcolm Turnbull's promise and advise the parliament whether or not the Minister for Home Affairs excused himself from all discussions on child care?
Mr MORRISON (Cook—Prime Minister) (14:49): I thank the member for his question. I will make inquiries of the department secretary and come back to the House.
Welfare Reform

Mr PITT (Hinkler) (14:50): My question is to the Minister for Families and Social Services. Will the minister update the House on how the government is standing together with local communities to expand the cashless debit card into new regions, helping welfare recipients to fight addiction and regain control of their lives? Is the minister aware of any alternative views?

Mr FLETCHER (Bradfield—Minister for Families and Social Services) (14:50): I do thank the member for Hinkler, who's been a very strong advocate for the cashless debit card. He's been a strong advocate for this program designed to reduce social harm caused by welfare-fuelled alcohol and drug abuse and gambling in areas with high levels of welfare dependency. He's been a particularly strong advocate for extending the cashless debit card to Bundaberg and Hervey Bay—this, I might say, in the face of trenchant opposition from Labor and the Greens. But, despite that trenchant opposition, the Morrison government has now delivered, has now secured legislative approval to extend the cashless debit card to Bundaberg and Hervey Bay with the legislation passing the Senate yesterday.

Of course, this builds on three existing trials in Ceduna, the Goldfields and East Kimberly. Significantly, the composition of people in the trial in Bundaberg and Hervey Bay will be 14 per cent Indigenous and the rest non-Indigenous. A very significant question indeed was asked by an ABC journalist yesterday speaking to the shadow minister. He said, 'So why would you'—meaning Labor—'support the trial in majority-Indigenous communities being extended but not support it being expanded to areas that are not majority Indigenous?' It's a very good question. What the shadow minister had to say in response to that was to assert that it had nothing to do with the demographics of the community. She said, 'There's not been a proper community consultation, which is patently clear.'

Let's look at the facts. Let's look at the facts in relation to consultation. Between May 2017 and December 2017, the Department of Social Services conducted over 188 meetings in the Bundaberg and Hervey Bay area. This included five meetings with Commonwealth government agencies, 19 meetings with community members, three meetings with the community reference group, two large community meetings with the public, 25 meetings with local government representatives, four meetings with peak bodies and 55 meetings with service providers, and yet the shadow minister says that there was not adequate consultation. There was extremely strong and extensive consultation because the principle is very clear: the cashless debit card is an initiative designed to reduce the negative impact of welfare-fuelled alcohol and drug abuse and gambling in areas with high levels of welfare dependency, which certainly includes Bundaberg and Hervey Bay. Where there is strong community support for it, we will introduce it, and that is what we are doing in Bundaberg and Hervey Bay. We're determined to make our welfare system work better. (Time expired)
Minister for Home Affairs

Mr DREYFUS (Isaacs—Deputy Manager of Opposition Business) (14:53): My question is to the Minister for Home Affairs. I refer to the minister's answer just now that he had recused himself from government discussions on child care. Is this an acknowledgement from the minister that he has a conflict of interest when it comes to the Commonwealth's dealings on child care?

Mr DUTTON (Dickson—Minister for Home Affairs) (14:53): The answer is no. In an abundance of care, I make the declaration of my wife's interests in relation to these matters, and that's been my practice for a long period of time.
Environment

Mr RICK WILSON (O'Connor) (14:54): My question is to the Minister for the Environment. Will the minister update the House on how the government is standing together with farmers and regional communities to give them the support they need by improving the environment? What are the alternative approaches, Minister?

Ms PRICE (Durack—Assistant Minister for the Environment) (14:54): What a great thrill to get my first question from the very, very good member for O'Connor, who represents some of the most productive agricultural land in Western Australia and some of the best mining provinces as well. He knows about all the problems that regional Western Australia and regional Australia face—issues that we on this side know a lot about.

As colleagues in this House well know, our regional communities are working hard every day to ensure that their local community and environment remain healthy and productive. Our farming communities, from Bencubbin in the west, which is in my electorate, out to Bundaberg in the electorate of the member for Hinkler, have a long history of sustainably managing our land for the production of world-class food and fibre while maintaining a healthy environment. We on this side know that farmers are the backbone of our country and that many people are currently suffering from the drought, but this coalition is backing those communities. Since 2013 this government has invested more than a billion dollars through our National Landcare Program. This is a program that delivers real outcomes for the environment and for landholders. Under this program we are treating more than 1.9 million hectares for weeds, including targeting the prickly pear in western Queensland. Eliminating weeds has a huge impact on properties, helping to get those productive paddocks back into action as well as providing a chance for native species to regenerate. We are culling damaging invasive animals across 2.2 million hectares. Eliminating those feral animals is positive news for regional communities. It keeps the land healthy for both agriculture and the environment. It's a true win-win.

Our Regional Land Partnerships is the flagship for the second phase of the National Landcare Program—$450 million over five years to ensure that local problems are solved by local solutions. This investment will help farmers to improve the productivity of their land. The Regional Land Partnerships will fund projects that protect our threatened ecological communities and support our most vulnerable native species.

But that's not all: the Emissions Reduction Fund is delivering real environmental benefits in a practical way that include providing an alternative income stream from the land for our farmers. These projects in the ERF make up $1.8 billion out of the $2.55 billion fund.

We understand that we can have policies that support agriculture and the environment at the same time. Unlike Labor, the coalition government understand regional communities, and they can trust us. They cannot trust those opposite.
Members of Parliament: Conduct

Ms CATHERINE KING (Ballarat) (14:57): My question is to the Prime Minister. I refer to his answer yesterday about bullying in his government. Is the Prime Minister aware the Minister for Women told 7.30:
… I've had conversations with many members of Parliament, both male and female, and it is clear to me that people were subject to threats and intimidation and bullying.
Why, then, did the Prime Minister yesterday deny there was a problem with bullying in his government? Who is right: the Minister for Women or the Prime Minister?

Mr MORRISON (Cook—Prime Minister) (14:58): I thank the member for her question. In relation to these matters, I have taken the opportunity to consult with the Chief Government Whip, as well as the whips in the Senate, and I have had the opportunity to engage directly with members in relation to the events of several weeks ago. We will continue to deal with any issues that arise from that within the normal process that we have followed as a party. I note that this morning the deputy leader of the Labor Party indicated that the Labor Party has exactly the same process: where issues are raised they are raised with the party whips and there is a process of members supporting each other through what can be—as the Labor Party would know, because they went through this on plenty of occasions—during those periods moments of intense lobbying and moments of a lot of pressure on all members. I'm absolutely satisfied that there was no gender-specific lobbying or pressure placed on members. I can also tell you one thing: it is not an institutionalised policy of the Liberal Party that you show and tell on your ballot, which is what is always done in the Labor Party.
Migration

Mr EVANS (Brisbane) (14:59): My question is to the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs. Will the minister update the House on how the government is standing together with Australians of all backgrounds to help ensure that our country remains the most successful multicultural society around the world? Is the minister aware of any other opinions?

Mr COLEMAN (Banks—Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs) (14:59): I thank the member for his question. We are a much stronger and more prosperous nation because of our proud heritage of immigration and multiculturalism. No matter where you go in Australia, you will find immigration success stories. In every town, every suburb, every football club and every church you will find immigration success stories. As we look around the country, we see small-business owners investing in Australia and creating jobs. We see people working hard, playing by the rules and raising their kids in search of a better life. We see professionals, community volunteers, the people who help build the backbone of our nation. What matters in Australia is what you contribute to our nation, not where you come from.

In the 19th century, of course, immigrants came overwhelmingly from the United Kingdom and from Ireland, but in more recent years we've welcomed people from around the globe—from Italy, from Greece, from China, from India, from Vietnam and so many other places. Being a citizen in our country is about committing to Australia and our values, like democracy and the rule of law, like so many millions of immigrants have done throughout our history. It doesn't matter whether you were born in Athens, in Armidale or in Apia; what matters is the commitment you make to the nation. As the Prime Minister says, being an Australian is about making a contribution, not taking a contribution. We have millions of immigration success stories in our nation that are a testament to just that principle. Nearly 70 per cent of our immigrants in the most recent year were skilled migrants, bringing important skills and economic activity to our nation. Businesses of immigrants employ some 1.4 million people, making a massive economic contribution to our nation, and the government will continue to back those people through tax support for small business and in so many other areas.

So we're a nation of immigrants and a nation of immigrant success stories. Importantly, we have an immigration system, under this government, with integrity. It was this Prime Minister who gave us back our border security and gave us back our immigration system with integrity. And it is this Minister for Home Affairs who has continued with that border security and that integrity of our immigration program, because we can never go back to the appalling legacy of Labor, of 50,000 unlawful arrivals, of 8,000 children in detention, of 1,200 deaths at sea. We will manage an immigration program with integrity. We'll manage an immigration program in support of our proud multicultural traditions.
Morrison Government

Mr ALBANESE (Grayndler) (15:02): My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister confirm that in the last fortnight the government's entire infrastructure plan was leaked, its plan to end its conflict with the Catholic school sector was leaked, its latest corporate tax plan was leaked, there was leaking about the PM plotting to tear down Malcolm Turnbull, and just today there was another leak about the now Prime Minister reportedly abusing the Tasmanian Treasurer? Is this what the Prime Minister meant when he said his own government was a muppet show?

Mr MORRISON (Cook—Prime Minister) (15:03): I'm happy to table the statement from the Treasurer of Tasmania, Mr Peter Gutwein, which I think puts to rest the issues that were reported today. I notice that those opposite got quite excited about this issue today, but, as usual, they come into this place and misrepresent facts, they misrepresent the position. We're used to it on this side of the House, that they can't be trusted, but those outside this place have also been learning for a long period of time that they cannot trust the leader of the Labor Party. They know that the leader of the Labor Party is not fair dinkum when it comes to the truth, he's not fair dinkum when it comes to what he believes in and he's not fair dinkum in his interactions with the Australian people, because he's been putting on a show. He's been putting on a show the entire time, and the Australian people are seeing through it.

What I can confirm is that this government does have a $75 billion rolling infrastructure program that is connecting our regions with ports and markets. I can confirm that we have a $1 billion congestion-busting fund which is dealing with the challenges of population growth in our suburbs. I can confirm that we have a tax policy which we were able to implement and legislate which is reducing the tax burden on small and medium sized businesses of less than $50 million. And I can confirm that the Labor Party, if they are elected, will increase the tax on every single one of those businesses, from the smallest business through to businesses up to $50 million. They will increase their legislated tax position of 25 per cent up to 27½ per cent. I also know that they will roll back the legislated tax cuts for households, for families, that give them relief—a tax burden that we are taking off by legislating the abolition of a complete tax schedule, a complete threshold, which will mean that there will be no-one paying more than 32½c in the dollar in 94 per cent of cases. We are delivering lower taxes. We are delivering cheaper electricity prices. We are ensuring that we are rolling out the infrastructure that Australians need.

I note that the member made reference to the conversation I had about GST. When will the leader of the Labor Party come clean on their position on the GST for Western Australia? Every time he goes to Western Australia he has a different position to his shadow Treasurer. They're for changing the formula; they're not for changing the formula. They're for 70 per cent; they're not for 70 per cent. They're for legislating; they're not for legislating. The people of Western Australia know that, when it comes to the leader of the Labor Party, he is a big phoney.
Infrastructure

Mr WOOD (La Trobe) (15:06): My question is to the Minister for Cities, Urban Infrastructure and Population. Will the minister update the House on how the government is standing together with Australian suburban communities to improve their quality of life through congestion-busting infrastructure? Is the minister aware of any alternative approaches?

Mr TUDGE (Aston—Minister for Cities, Urban Infrastructure and Population) (15:07): I thank the member for La Trobe for his question. It was a pleasure to visit his electorate just last week with the Prime Minister, in Berwick and in Pakenham—two of the fastest-growing areas in Melbourne and indeed in the country—to see some of those local hotspots. We saw them on McGregor Road. We saw them on Clyde Road, in Berwick. The member for La Trobe is fighting very hard to get those hotspots finished.

Along with addressing local hotspots, this government is also investing in major congestion-busting infrastructure right across the country. In the budget this year, one of those projects that we announced was a $475 million commitment to finally build the Monash Rail. This would go from the Dandenong line at Huntingdale, connect up Monash University and eventually go all the way out to Rowville. In doing so, it would finally connect up Australia's largest university campus to the Metro rail. There are 55,000 students who use that university campus. They will finally be connected to the Metro rail. It will also connect up the second-biggest employment cluster in Melbourne, being in the Clayton area, to the Metro rail. It will take traffic off the street. Believe it or not, the bus link from Monash through to Huntingdale at present is the single busiest bus route in the country. We'll be taking those buses off the busy roads.

Earlier studies also suggest—and I know the member for La Trobe is particularly interested in this—that, if we build this rail link, it will take the equivalent of a lane of traffic off the Monash Freeway. The member for La Trobe knows how congested that freeway is, despite the fact we're investing an extra billion dollars to widen that freeway to support those members out there. This is just one element out of a $75 billion package that the government is putting towards congestion-busting infrastructure across the country.

I am asked about alternatives by the member for La Trobe. This project, the Rowville-Monash rail, has been on the books since 1959. Believe it or not, we are the first government to put serious dollars into that project. And I ask: what is the opposition doing in relation to this project, in relation to the 55,000 students and in relation to those people stuck on the Monash Freeway? There's stony silence from the other side. The question is: how many more decades will they have to wait for the Labor Party to finally commit to this congestion-busting infrastructure to build the Monash-Rowville rail?
QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE: ADDITIONAL ANSWERS
Drought
The SPEAKER (15:10): The Prime Minister, on indulgence.

Mr MORRISON (Cook—Prime Minister) (15:10): I'll just add to an answer from earlier today. Earlier today I was asked by the member for Hunter about a post on my social media feed. He represented that this was a view that I had apparently stated. That was the clear implication of the member for Hunter.
Opposition members: No, he didn't!
The SPEAKER: The Prime Minister will pause for a second. The Prime Minister's adding to an answer. I want to hear what he's saying. Those who don't want to hear will be ejected.
Mr MORRISON: I'm happy to respond to the member for Hunter.
Dr Mike Kelly interjecting—

The SPEAKER: The member for Eden-Monaro can leave under 94(a). He's been interjecting right through the day. He won't, by way of interjection, try and direct me. I think it would be a better use of his time to read the Practice around this area. The Prime Minister, if you could start again.

Mr MORRISON: Thank you, Mr Speaker. I'll continue. What the post refers to is comments from feedlot operators from the north-west of New South Wales, Michael in Bellata and Sandy from near Moree, who are explaining what the drought means for them. It goes through a range of comments. There's another one from Mr Munroe that says: 'We know it will rain again. It always has. We've had droughts before, and we'll have them again. We'll get through this one. And most farmers—they're good operators—will survive because, to some extent, they have prepared in what way they can for this current event.'

The way our government is responding to the drought is to go out there and listen to what people in rural and regional communities are saying to us. I'm not going to censor their views; I'm going to listen to their views. That's what the member for New England is doing as the special envoy on drought. He's out there listening to, talking to and getting the feedback off farming communities in drought-affected areas. The Labor Party might want to close their ears to the voices of the bush, but the Liberal-National government never will. On that note, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
Mr FITZGIBBON (Hunter) (15:12): I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
The SPEAKER: Does the member for Hunter claim to have been misrepresented?
Mr FITZGIBBON: I do indeed, just now by the Prime Minister.
The SPEAKER: The member for Hunter may proceed.

Mr FITZGIBBON: In adding to an answer to a question I asked him during question time, the Prime Minister said that I attributed to him words that were contained in a video which he put on his social media. The question I asked him today, excluding the quote I used—and there were a number of hurtful quotes in that video, which I won't repeat here; I used one only. In addition to the quote, there were three paragraphs in my question. In the first paragraph, I asked, 'Why did the Prime Minister tweet and authorise a video?' In the second paragraph, I suggested that neither the member for Warringah nor Malcolm Turnbull would ever promote a statement—

The SPEAKER: If the member for Hunter could just pause for a second. With a personal explanation, you don't need to repeat the question. Hansard's got that. You need to say where you believe you've been misrepresented.
Mr FITZGIBBON: Which is exactly what I'm doing because—
The SPEAKER: No, you're not. You're just repeating the question.
Mr FITZGIBBON: In the third paragraph, I said—

The SPEAKER: If the member for Hunter's going to ignore me—I have enormous tolerance in this area, but I've asked him to not repeat the question. We've all heard the question. Those who aren't familiar with it can go and look it up. He needs to go to where he's been misrepresented in his view or he's going to resume his seat.

Mr FITZGIBBON: I have been misrepresented because the Prime Minister said that I attributed those words to him, whereas clearly I said, in each paragraph, that he had promoted the video. So the question stands, Mr Speaker. He has promoted the video and everything contained within it.
The SPEAKER: I thank the member for Hunter. He's outlined where he believes he's been misrepresented.
STATEMENT BY THE SPEAKER

subdebateinfo.title: Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory: Remonstrance

p.span: Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory: Remonstrance

The SPEAKER (15:14): Before we go to the matter of public importance, I inform the House that I have received from the Speaker of the Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory a remonstrance of the legislative assembly requesting that the federal parliament not determine and distinguish between the rights of Australian citizens by virtue of where those Australians reside within the country and that the House of Representatives repeal section 50A of the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act 1978. The remonstrance will form part of the records of the House and copies have been placed on the table.
REQUEST TO THE PARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIA
MOTION: TERRITORY RIGHTS
On Thursday 23 August 2018, Mr Gunner (Chief Minister), pursuant to notice, moved:
(1)That this Assembly recognises:
(a)Australia's democracy is one of the best in the world;
(b)Territory rights are of paramount importance to citizens of the Northern Territory of Australia;

(c)the actions of the Australian Senate on the evening of 15 August 2018 in failing to agree to a legislative proposal to restore the rights of both the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory to consider and pass legislation on behalf of the residents of those Australian territories is a breach of democratic principles for Territorians;
(d)specifically, the failure of the Australian Parliament to repeal section 50A of the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act 1978remains an impediment to democracy for Territorians;

(e)the ongoing disparity between the legislators elected by the residents of Australian territories and those elected to represent the people in the Australian states in relation to legislative capacity is anti-democratic;

(f)the distinction between the capacity to legislate and any actual legislation about the rights of terminally ill persons in the Northern Territory appears to have been deliberately confused by some Senators; and
(2)This Assembly requests that:
(a)the Federal Parliament not determine and distinguish between the rights of Australian citizens by virtue of where those Australians reside within this country; and
(b)the House of Representatives as soon as practicable consider and pass legislation to repeal section 50A of the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act 1978.
THE MOTION WAS AGREED TO
Hon Kezia Purick MLA
Speaker

span.span: The member for Lingiari, on indulgence?

p.span: Mr SNOWDON (Lingiari) (15:15): I want to thank my colleagues from the Northern Territory for bringing this remonstrance to the parliament and representing the view of the member for Solomon and myself that the Senate, in opposing legislation which would have recognised the rights of Territorians in this place, has done the wrong thing, and we in this House should change that.

The SPEAKER: I thank the member for Lingiari. Given he's made a statement, I would like to point out to him that the member for Solomon accompanied me with the Speaker earlier in the day, when that was presented to me.
MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
Independent Integrity Commission
The SPEAKER (15:15): I've received a letter from the honourable member for Denison proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:
The urgent need for a federal independent integrity commission.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

span.span: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

p.span: Mr WILKIE (Denison) (15:15): I start by pointing out that since 2012 Australia has fallen six places on the international corruption perception index. I also refer to some excellent research by the Australia Institute, which indicates that 85 per cent of Australians think there is corruption in federal politics. Indeed, the perception of corruption impacts business investment and the efficient allocation of resources, thereby reducing our GDP by about four per cent or a thumping $72.3 billion a year.

This is a dreadful situation, but it's completely understandable, because when you look around us and look at our recent history, scandal after scandal and question after question raised about conduct, at the federal level in particular, you can understand why 85 per cent of Australians think there is indeed corruption in federal politics. I have a few examples. Who can forget the Australian Wheat Board being caught up in the bribery scandal with Saddam Hussein when selling wheat into Iraq? Who could forget how the Reserve Bank was caught up in the bribery scandal related to winning note-printing contracts abroad? What about, just very recently, a former member of this House, Mr Bruce Billson? He was the executive chair of the Franchise Council of Australia while he was the Minister for Small Business. That's right. Bruce Billson sat in this place as a minister of the Crown, the Minister for Small Business, when he was at the same time the executive chair of the Franchise Council of Australia. What about former minister Andrew Robb? He was the trade minister when the Chinese company Landbridge secured the 99-year lease for the Port of Darwin. It was a company that Mr Robb then went and worked part-time on an income of almost $1 million a year. No wonder 85 per cent of Australians think there is corruption in federal politics. Who could forget the secrecy over the mysterious federal government grant of $30 million to Foxtel? What about more recently? There was an even more mysterious grant, seemingly on a whim, of $444 million to the Great Barrier Reef Foundation. I'm going to labour this point to death: no wonder 85 per cent of Australians think there is corruption in federal politics. No wonder the overwhelming majority of Australians are strongly of the view that there is a need for some sort of federal integrity commission, perhaps modelled along the lines of the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption.

Of course, the New South Wales ICAC has been wonderfully successful since it was established. A number of people have found themselves in prison, and many parliamentarians have been forced to resign from the New South Wales parliament. What a wonderful example of the effectiveness of having some sort of corruption body at an appropriate level.

I stood with my colleague the member for Mayo and Senator McKim from the Greens outside the Magistrates Court here in the ACT just today because today is the day that the directions hearing will be conducted into the Witness K and Bernard Collaery matter. What better example is there? In fact, if I only had time for one example of why we need a federal integrity commission, I would refer to the Witness K and Bernard Collaery matter.

In 2004, the Australian government, the then Howard government, had the Australian Secret Intelligence Service plant bugs in the East Timor parliamentary building in order to eavesdrop on the confidential and highly sensitive joint venture partner negotiations over the sharing of the oil and gas revenue from the Timor Gap. It was something that was and remains clearly illegal under Australian law. It is clearly illegal under Australian law to use one of our foreign intelligence agencies to eavesdrop or spy on confidential joint venture partner commercial negotiations. What is the federal government doing about it? It's charged the whistleblower, Witness K, who's trying to shine a light on government misconduct and charged his lawyer, who is doing nothing more than representing his client and who felt compelled to speak to some journalists to shine a light on this most serious federal government misconduct.

It is self-evident that Australia needs a federal integrity commission. It is remarkable that every state and territory now has or is putting in place an integrity watchdog. In my home state of Tasmania, we have the Integrity Commission. Yes, in Tasmania we might criticise the Integrity Commission and say it's not effective enough and we want it enhanced, but at least we have something.
